transcript:
Patient: Last session, we talked about how I could start volunteering at the community center or pursue my photography more seriously. I did some research on the community center's website and looked into their volunteer opportunities, but I haven't reached out to them yet. I guess I'm a little nervous about putting myself out there and committing to something new.

Therapist: It's understandable to feel nervous about taking that first step. Let's explore what thoughts or beliefs might be holding you back from reaching out to the community center. When you imagine yourself volunteering there, what goes through your mind?

Patient: I worry that I won't be good enough or that I'll let them down somehow. I've been out of the workforce for a while now, and I'm not sure if my skills are still relevant. I also worry about what other people will think of me, especially since I'm transgender. I don't want to deal with any judgment or discrimination.

Therapist: Those are valid concerns, and it's brave of you to share them. It sounds like there might be some cognitive distortions at play here, such as mind-reading (assuming others will judge you) and catastrophizing (expecting the worst-case scenario). Let's look at the evidence for and against these thoughts. What skills or strengths do you have that would make you a valuable volunteer?

Patient: Well, I have a lot of experience working with marginalized communities, especially LGBTQ+ youth. I'm a good listener and I'm passionate about helping others. And even though I've been retired for a couple of years, I've stayed involved with my support group and mentored a young transgender woman, so I haven't completely lost touch with that world.

Therapist: That's great evidence against the thought that you're not good enough or that your skills aren't relevant. It sounds like you have a lot to offer as a volunteer. Now, let's consider the possibility of facing judgment or discrimination. While it's true that some people may have prejudiced views, is it accurate to assume that everyone at the community center will judge you based on your gender identity?

Patient: I guess not. I'm sure there are plenty of open-minded people there too, especially since it's a community center that serves diverse populations. And even if I do encounter some judgment, I've dealt with that before and I know I can handle it.

Therapist: That's a great insight. So, based on this evidence, how could we reframe your original thoughts about volunteering?

Patient: Instead of assuming I'm not good enough, I could remind myself of my skills and experience and trust that I have something valuable to offer. And instead of expecting judgment from everyone, I could focus on the potential for positive connections and the fact that I've overcome prejudice before.

Therapist: I love that reframing. It's more balanced and empowering. Now, let's think about how you could apply Opposite Action in this situation. If your instinct is to avoid reaching out because of fear, what would be the opposite action?

Patient: The opposite action would be to go ahead and contact the community center, even though it scares me. I could send an email or make a phone call to inquire about volunteer opportunities and express my interest.

Therapist: That's a great idea. Taking that opposite action can help you build confidence and challenge your fears. And remember, even if it doesn't work out perfectly, that doesn't mean you're not good enough or that you've failed. It's just one experience, and there will be other opportunities to try again.

Patient: You're right. I don't have to put so much pressure on myself to get it right the first time. I can just take it one step at a time and see what happens.

Therapist: Exactly. And we can continue to work on reframing those negative thoughts and beliefs as you take these steps. I'm here to support you every step of the way.

Patient: Thank you, Nova. I feel a little more hopeful now about reaching out to the community center. I think I'm going to set a goal for myself to send that email by the end of the week.

Therapist: That's a great goal! Let's break it down into smaller steps. What do you need to do first in order to send that email?

Patient: I guess I need to draft the email and figure out what I want to say. I could jot down some notes about my relevant experience and why I'm interested in volunteering.

Therapist: That's a great first step. And remember, you don't have to have it all figured out in the email. You can just express your interest and ask for more information about the opportunities available. The goal is just to make that initial contact and open the door to further conversation.

Patient: Okay, that feels more manageable. I can start working on that draft today and give myself a few days to refine it before I send it.

Therapist: That's a great plan. And remember, even if you don't hear back right away or if they don't have any immediate openings, that doesn't mean you're not good enough or that you've failed. It just means that particular opportunity wasn't the right fit, and there will be other chances to try again.

Patient: You're right. I need to keep that perspective and not get too discouraged if it doesn't work out right away. I can keep looking for other opportunities and just focus on taking one step at a time.

Therapist: Exactly. And we can continue to work on challenging those negative thoughts and beliefs as you take these steps. I'm here to support you every step of the way. So, for homework this week, your goal is to draft and send that email to the community center. We can review how it went at our next session and continue to work on building your sense of purpose and challenging those negative beliefs.

Patient: That sounds good. I feel more motivated now to take that first step. Thank you for your support and encouragement, Nova.

Therapist: You're welcome, Alexis. I'm proud of you for being willing to face your fears and take action towards your goals. Remember, progress isn't always linear, and there will be ups and downs along the way. The important thing is that you keep taking small steps forward and don't give up on yourself. I believe in you and I know you have so much to offer.
